Issues.Title: @let validation fixes
Issues.Body:
Fixes a couple of issues when we check if a `@let` declaration is used before it is defined:

### fix(compiler-cli): avoid duplicate diagnostics for let declarations read before definition
Fixes that in some cases `@let` declarations that are read before they're defined were producing multiple diagnostics.

### fix(compiler-cli): used before declared diagnostic not firing for control flow blocks
When we process `@if` and `@for` blocks, we create a scope around their expressions in order to encapsulate the aliases to them. The problem is that this doesn't represent the actual structure since the expression is part of the outer scope. This surfaces by not raising the "used before declared" diagnostic for `@let` declarations.

These changes resolve the issue by processing the expression as a part of the parent scope.

Fixes #56842.

Issues.Title: Improve the type error message for unassignable form groups
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

forms

### Description

Search terms: _FormGroup not assignable_, _TS2322_, _2322_

When a typed reactive form requires data from a service, it cannot be created in the constructor. Rather, we need to declare the form in the component and separately instantiate it after the constructor has run, usually in the ngOnInit hook.

Separating the declaration steps from the initialization step can lead to the two types misaligning, which causes an error like the following:

```
Type 'FormGroup<{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string | null>; }>' is not assignable to type 'FormGroup<{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string>; }>'.
  Types of property 'controls' are incompatible.
    Type '{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string | null>; }' is not assignable to type '{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string>; }'.(2322)
```

[Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-4ld5bn?file=src%2Fmain.ts)

This is a small example, but already it gets hard to parse. The issue is that one of the form controls wasn’t marked as nonNullable during initialization, and `FormControl<string|null>` is not assignable to `FormControl<string>`. Now imagine you have a Form with multiple levels of nested FormArrays and FormGroups and one control is out of sync with its declaration. It is a nightmare to debug.

### Proposed solution

When a FormGroup instance is not assignable to a variable of FormType, the error message should indicate the paths of the offending control(s) in both the instantiated and declared types. This could be done similarly to how TypeScript handles incompatible structured types:

```typescript
type Declaration = {
    a: string
    b: {
        b1: string
    }
}

type Instantiation = {
    a: string
    b: {
        b1: string | null
    }
}

let decl: Declaration
let inst!: Instantiation

decl = inst
```

```
Type 'Instantiation' is not assignable to type 'Declaration'.
  The types of 'b.b1' are incompatible between these types.
    Type 'string | null' is not assignable to type 'string'.
      Type 'null' is not assignable to type 'string'.(2322)
```
[TS Playground](https://www.typescriptlang.org/play/?#code/C4TwDgpgBAIhDGAbAhgJ2cAlgewHZQF4oBvAWACgoqpkAuKAZ2FU1wHMLqoAjesyrtW4BGekxbtO1AL4VZ5CqEhQAkribJcWDDnxF+XOo2asOAqrxJTBPUcYlsoAHyi4ArokTWo8+RUQQwFAAJgiI9HBIaDp4-oFQrEwAhPRqGlqYMbgUFKFIhAnqwEA)

I say “in both the instantiated and declared types” to catch the case where one type has more form controls than the other – this case is handled by this error message in TS:

```
Property 'b' is missing in type 'Instantiation' but required in type 'Declaration'.(2741)
```

When two form controls differ in type, then the error message should unwrap the types of the controls and explain why they’re not assignable. In the example above, this might look like this:

```
Type 'FormGroup<{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string | null>; }>' is not assignable to type 'FormGroup<{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string>; }>'.
  Types of property 'controls' are incompatible.
    Type '{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string | null>; }' is not assignable to type '{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string>; }'.
       The types of 'c' are incompatible between these types.
         Type 'string | null' is not assignable to type 'string'.
           Type 'null' is not assignable to type 'string'.(2322)
```

### Alternatives considered

None.

Issues.Title: Non-existent pages return `200`, but should return `404` http status
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

Non-existent pages, e.g. https://angular.dev/this-page-does-not-exist, are expected to return `404` http status. Instead, all bad URLs return http `200` and dynamically inject the 'page not found' message to the user.

The incorrect `200` status code informs web crawlers that the requested page is valid. The lack of actual useful content on that page might negatively affect ranking as those pages will be deemed to not have any relevant content on them.

The incorrect `200` status code makes it difficult to detect broken links, incl. those internal to the site. As an example, this issue was discovered while diagnosing broken page,`https://angular.dev/api/animations/%C9%B5AnimationGroupPlayer` (see #56850).

Issues.Title: fix(zone.js): support `Timeout.refresh` in Node.js
Issues.Body:
The `Timeout` object in Node.js has a `refresh` method, used to restart `setTimeout`/`setInterval` timers. Before this commit, `Timeout.refresh` was not handled, leading to memory leaks when using `fetch` in Node.js. This issue arose because `undici` (the Node.js fetch implementation) uses a refreshed `setTimeout` for cleanup operations.

For reference, see: https://github.com/nodejs/undici/blob/1dff4fd9b1b2cee97c5f8cf44041521a62d3f133/lib/util/timers.js#L45

Fixes: #56586

function isEsbuildBased(builderName) {

        return true;
    }
    return false;
}
```

i have my custom builder name there.

I might be missing something here, but there is no documentation for these cases. As I am not an expert, it has been quite challenging to understand how this should work. I would greatly appreciate any help you can provide!

Thank you in advance for your assistance.

Issues.Title: Allow creating git local user with new project before making first commit
Issues.Body:
### Command

new

### Description

I need to keep multiple git identities on my computer. When creating `ng new` I need to have control over which identity is used to create the project, as I don't always want to use the `--global` git user. I often forget run into situations where I create a new project with wrong identity.


### Describe the solution you'd like

The solution I'd prefer would be some sort of micro-routine that would allow creating local project `user.*` config and then make the initial commit utilizing it, without the need of using the commit skipping flag.

Imagine this syntax (just an example):

  `ng new --git-local-user` or `ng new -G`

The script creates a new project, but before it gets to making git commit, it shows a radio-button menu:
```
(*) create local git user
( ) use global git user (abcxyz)
```

Selecting create would prompt for user name and then user email and once done, make the first commit as it would normally do.


### Describe alternatives you've considered

You can either:

1. `--commit false` and then manually: create local user, `git add .`, `git commit` 
2. Erase `git config --global user.*` entries to deliberately make the git fail, but this is kind of harsh

None of those offers nice Dx.

With just one new flag you'd get a nice and consistent cli behavior and would get the entire flow with some extra git helper routine.

***This release deliberately contains backwards-incompatible changes.*** To avoid automatically picking up releases like this, you should either be pinning the exact version of `esbuild` in your `package.json` file (recommended) or be using a version range syntax that only accepts patch upgrades such as `^0.22.0` or `~0.22.0`.     I've just been made aware that Amazon doesn't pin their dependencies in their "AWS CDK" product, which means that whenever esbuild publishes a new release, many people (potentially everyone?) using their SDK around the world instantly starts using it without Amazon checking that it works first. This change in version 0.22.0 happened to break their SDK. I'm amazed that things haven't broken before this point. This revert attempts to avoid these problems for Amazon's customers. Hopefully Amazon will pin their dependencies in the future.

-   Fix preserving collapsed JSX whitespace ([#​3818](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3818))

However, the whitespace should only be ignored if the JSX is being transformed, not if it's being preserved. Issues.Title: feat(@angular/build): support WASM/ES Module integration proposal
Issues.Body:
Application builds will now support the direct import of WASM files. The behavior follows the WebAssembly/ES module integration proposal. The usage of this feature requires the ability to use native async/await and top-level await. Due to this requirement, applications must be zoneless to use this new feature. Applications that use Zone.js are currently incompatible and an error will be generated if the feature is used in a Zone.js application. Manual setup of a WASM file is, however, possible in a Zone.js application if WASM usage is required. Further details for manual setup can be found here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/WebAssembly/Loading_and_running

The following is a brief example of using a WASM file in the new feature with the integration proposal behavior:
```
import { multiply } from './example.wasm';

console.log(multiply(4, 5));
```

NOTE: TypeScript will not automatically understand the types for WASM files. Type definition files will need to be created for each WASM file to allow for an error-free build. These type definition files are specific to each individual WASM file and will either need to be manually created or provided by library authors.

The feature relies on an active proposal which may change as it progresses through the standardization process. This may result in behavioral differences between versions.
Proposal Details: https://github.com/WebAssembly/esm-integration/tree/main/proposals/esm-integration

For more information regarding zoneless applications, you can visit https://angular.dev/guide/experimental/zoneless

Issues.Title: Add support for esbuild chunkNames option
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

The application builder does not provide all the options esbuild does ; I think the possibility to customize further the output location is interesting though.

As esbuild propose options to control the file names of automatically generated chunks (https://esbuild.github.io/api/#chunk-names), it could be a nice addition of options available through the application builder schema.

The same strategy could maybe be applied with similar `assetNames` option.

### Describe the solution you'd like

To be able to control it for all chunks, I guess a good location for this templating string would be in the `outputPath` object like

```json
{
  "build": {
    "executor": "",            
    "options": {
      "outputPath": {
        "base": "dist",
        "browser": "prod",
        "server": "server",
        "media": "media",
        "browserChunkNames": "front-[ext]/[name]_[hash]",
        "serverChunkNames": "example--[hash]"
      },
  ...
  }
}
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I'm currently using the application builder via the @nx/angular:application that, in addition of the cli builder features, add the suport of providing esbuild plugins.

Unfortunately I didn't manage to find or write a plugin that can infer on the generated files, issues are open on this subject on esbuild to have callbacks such as "onEmit" for instance but as there is an existing option for the scenario, better use it.

Thanks for reading.

Issues.Title: Reduce angular uses of file watcher by leveraging folder watcher (ex: ng serve)
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Description

I keep reaching the ENOSPC watcher errors with angular.

It would be nice for angular `ng serve` to be less ressource hungry by reusing folder watchers instead of file watchers. This would also reduce the need for "file watch filtering".

### Describe the solution you'd like

According to inotify man page angular watcher could use folder watches instead of watching file reducing the amount of watcher greatly (reusing a single inotify watcher per watched folder instead of one watcher file actual file).

The code would have to do the actual filtering on event reception to known if the item was watched (the event includes a file `name` attribute for folder watch allowing to known which file changed).

```
NAME         [top](https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/inotify.7.html#top_of_page)
       inotify - monitoring filesystem events
DESCRIPTION         [top](https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/inotify.7.html#top_of_page)
       The inotify API provides a mechanism for monitoring filesystem
       events.  Inotify can be used to monitor individual files, or to
       monitor directories.  When a directory is monitored, inotify will
       return events for the directory itself, and for files inside the
       directory.

[...]

The name field is present only when an event is returned for a
       file inside a watched directory; it identifies the filename
       within the watched directory.  This filename is null-terminated,
       and may include further null bytes ('\0') to align subsequent
       reads to a suitable address boundary.
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

The suggested alternative on the internet is to increase the sysctl limit for watchers at the cost of a kernel memory usage increase.

After clicking on an option in a chips-autocomplete, the input should reflect the signal state correctly.

### Actual Behavior

After clicking on an option in a chips-autocomplete, the input is not updated according to the signal state.

Issues.Title: bug(MatChipGrid): Focus order is not logical
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Multiple labels are added in a custom grid. The order in which focusable elements receive focus in the grid is not logical. The RIGHT and LEFT ARROW keys move right and left, but the DOWN and UP ARROW keys also move right and left. This is acceptable for users who can see the structure, but for screen reader users it interferes with understanding the grid structure.

Ensure that the order in which elements receive keyboard focus follows a meaningful and logical sequence. DOWN ARROW and UP ARROW should only move between logical rows of the filter grid, as in the [ARIA APG pattern](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/grid/examples/layout-grids/#ex2_label).

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/run?file=package.json
Steps to reproduce:
1. Navigate through the chips with input example
2. Notice that RIGHT and LEFT ARROW keys have the same effect as the DOWN and UP ARROW keys

DOWN and UP ARROW keys should move the focus from

Lemon -> Lime -> Apple

### Actual Behavior

DOWN and UP ARROW keys moves the focus from

Lemon -> Close icon (Lemon) -> Lime -> Close icon (Lime) -> Apple -> Close icon (Apple)
